blocks.description: Expression for the probability of an error.

blocks.text: Now $x_i$ etc. are quite independent, so that the probability of all the errors falling within the range $x$ will be the product of the separate probabilities.

Hence we have obtained an expression which gives us the probability of a certain error falling within a range.  We might say that if the errors were kept within the range $x$, the calculated result would be a nearer approximation to truth than if the range were greater.
Our object then is to find when the probability of a small error ($x$ may be reduced as we please) is greater, i.e., to find when $P$ is a maximum.

blocks.description: Expression for the probability as a function of errors.

blocks.text: and the smaller the denominator is made, the larger will $P$ become. But the only variable in the denominator is $x^2$ and hence, under the condition that $P$ may have its maximum value, $x$ must be the least possible. Hence the most probable value of the quantity to be determined is that which makes the sum of the squares of the errors minimal.
The fact can now be established that the arithmetic mean of the observed values is the most probable value of the quantity.
